text: [Music]
I it began in the early 60s uh I was
growing up in Washington uh my father
worked for President Kennedy and for me
the ultimate uh career goal was the
Peace Corp and while I never actually
served in the Peace Corp uh the
inspiration of that time and of that
movement in particular to serve um has
motivated
probably my all my life and work since
that time uh and I was um very
privileged
to to meet a man many many worlds away
from from uh where I was born who shared
the same values and the same um
aspiration and and commitment to public
service that I had grown up with though
we had grown up in such different
environments King Hussein was that
quintessential um and unique actually um
Middle Eastern leader for whom who
understood his role as as a public
servant and not as a uh more
conventional ruler if you will for him
it was about service and that is what
joined our hearts and and and then our
work together uh so I was able to play a
role in trying to bridge worlds and to
take my experience um prior to my
marriage and um and then the most
important component that I have
emphasized today and and and do
throughout of listening and learning um
be as I began my service um in in as a
public servant in in in the Middle East
uh so my service uh began as a young
woman marching and advocating for the
mission of Martin Luther King and and uh
dreaming of the Peace Corp in the United
States in the 60s and then evolved into
someone trying to bring these two worlds
together and and finding common ground
in in in the Arab and the Muslim world
with the values and ideals I'd grown up
with in this country and it continues to
this day
